template.name: Storage Lenovo ix4-300d
template.description:
## Overview
SNMPv3 Template for Lenovo NAS ix4-300d: this template monitor RAID, FAN , Disk partitions, Connected users, Network interfaces and device temperature.
- 11 items
- 5 Triggers
- 8 Discovery
## Author
Hamdi Ben Abdallah

item.name: Memory size
item.description: The amount of physical read-write main memory, typically RAM, contained by the host.

item.name: Maximum number of processes
item.description: The maximum number of process contexts this system can support. If there is no fixed maximum, the value should be zero. On systems that have a fixed maximum this object can help diagnose failures that occur when this maximum is reached.

valuemap.name: Lenovo EMC Storage - Maximum Number of Processes

item.name: Number of processes
item.description: The number of process contexts currently loaded or running on this system.

item.name: Device uptime
item.description: The amount of time since this host was last initialized. Note that this is different from sysUpTime in the SNMPv2-MIB [RFC1907] because sysUpTime is the uptime of the network management portion of the system.

valuemap.name: Lenovo EMC Storage - Media Service status

trigger.name: Media service status was changed for: {ITEM.LASTVALUE}

valuemap.name: Lenovo EMC Storage - Remote access status

trigger.name: Remote access status was changed for: {ITEM.LASTVALUE}
RAID status require attention: {ITEM.LASTVALUE}
trigger.description: Verifiy your device for more infos.

item.name: System uptime
item.description: The time (in hundredths of a second) since the network management portion of the system was last re-initialized.

discovery_rule.name: Connected Clients
discovery_rule.description: Protocol used by this kind of clients

item_prototype.name: Disk size of $1
item_prototype.description: Capacity of disk

item_prototype.name: Disk status of $1
item_prototype.description:
Status of Disk. There are four status:
NORMAL FOREIGN FAULTED MISSING

discovery_rule.name: Disk Names
discovery_rule.description: An entry of one disk I/O performance.

item_prototype.name: IO average queue length of $1
item_prototype.description: Average queue length.

item_prototype.name: IO average service time at disk of $1
item_prototype.description: Average service time at disk.

item_prototype.name: IO average disk utilization of $1
item_prototype.description: Average disk utilization.

item_prototype.name: IO average waiting time of $1
item_prototype.description: Average waiting time (queue + service)

item_prototype.name: IO CPU time (%) of $1
item_prototype.description: Percentage of CPU time during which I/O requests were issued to the device.

item_prototype.name: IO kilobytes read per second of $1
item_prototype.description: Kilobytes read per second.

item_prototype.name: IO kilobytes write per second of $1
item_prototype.description: Kilobytes written per second.

item_prototype.name: IO read merges per second of $1
item_prototype.description: Read merges per second.

item_prototype.name: IO write merges per second of $1
item_prototype.description: Write merges per second.

item_prototype.name: IO read requests per second of $1
item_prototype.description: Read io requests per second.

item_prototype.name: IO write requests per second of $1
item_prototype.description: Write io requests per second.

discovery_rule.name: Disk Partitions

condition.value: @Lenovo EMC Storage - SNMP Discovery Disk Partitions

discovery_rule.description: The (conceptual) table of logical storage areas on the host. An entry shall be placed in the storage table for each logical area of storage that is allocated and has fixed resource limits. The amount of storage represented in an entity is the amount actually usable by the requesting entity, and excludes loss due to formatting or file system reference information. These entries are associated with logical storage areas, as might be seen by an application, rather than physical storage entities which are typically seen by an operating system. Storage such as tapes and floppies without file systems on them are typically not allocated in chunks by the operating system to requesting applications, and therefore shouldn't appear in this table. Examples of valid storage for this table include disk partitions, file systems, ram (for some architectures this is further segmented into regular memory, extended memory, and so on), backing store for virtual memory (`swap space'). This table is intended to be a useful diagnostic for `out of memory' and `out of buffers' types of failures. In addition, it can be a useful performance monitoring tool for tracking memory, disk, or buffer usage.

item_prototype.name: Allocations Units on $1
item_prototype.description: The size, in bytes, of the data objects allocated from this pool. If this entry is monitoring sectors, blocks, buffers, or packets, for example, this number will commonly be greater than one. Otherwise this number will typically be one.

item_prototype.name: Storage total size in Bytes on $1
item_prototype.description: The real size of the storage in Bytes. hrStorageSize * hrStorageAllocationUnits.

item_prototype.name: Storage total size on $1
item_prototype.description: The size of the storage represented by this entry, in units of hrStorageAllocationUnits. This object is writable to allow remote configuration of the size of the storage area in those cases where such an operation makes sense and is possible on the underlying system. For example, the amount of main memory allocated to a buffer pool might be modified or the amount of disk space allocated to virtual memory might be modified.

item_prototype.name: Storage used in Bytes on $1
item_prototype.description: The storage used in Bytes. hrStorageUsed * hrStorageAllocationUnits.

item_prototype.name: Storage used on $1
item_prototype.description: The amount of the storage represented by this entry that is allocated, in units of hrStorageAllocationUnits.

trigger_prototype.name: Free disk space is less than 2% on volume {#SNMPVALUE}
Free disk space is less than 10% on volume {#SNMPVALUE}

dependency.name: Free disk space is less than 2% on volume {#SNMPVALUE}

discovery_rule.name: Network interfaces

condition.value: @Lenovo EMC Storage - SNMP Discovery Network Interfaces

discovery_rule.description: You may also consider using IF-MIB::ifType or IF-MIB::ifAlias for discovery depending on your filtering needs.

item_prototype.name: Description of interface $1
item_prototype.description: A textual string containing information about the interface. This string should include the name of the manufacturer, the product name and the version of the interface hardware/software.

item_prototype.name: Inbound errors on interface $1
item_prototype.description: For packet-oriented interfaces, the number of inbound packets that contained errors preventing them from being deliverable to a higher-layer protocol. For character-oriented or fixed-length interfaces, the number of inbound transmission units that contained errors preventing them from being deliverable to a higher-layer protocol.

item_prototype.name: Incoming traffic on interface $1
item_prototype.description: The number of octets in valid MAC frames received on this interface, including the MAC header and FCS.

item_prototype.name: Operational status of interface $1
item_prototype.description: The current operational state of the interface.

trigger_prototype.name: Operational status was changed on {HOST.NAME} interface {#SNMPVALUE}

item_prototype.name: Outbound errors on interface $1
item_prototype.description: For packet-oriented interfaces, the number of outbound packets that could not be transmitted because of errors. For character-oriented or fixed-length interfaces, the number of outbound transmission units that could not be transmitted because of errors.

item_prototype.name: Outgoing traffic on interface $1
item_prototype.description: The number of octets transmitted in MAC frames on this interface, including the MAC header and FCS.

item_prototype.name: Physical Address of interface $1
item_prototype.description: The interface's address at the protocol layer immediately `below' the network layer in the protocol stack. For interfaces which do not have such an address (e.g., a serial line), this object should contain an octet string of zero length.

dependency.name: Temperature of {#SNMPVALUE} is to very high: {ITEM.LASTVALUE}

trigger_prototype.name: Temperature of {#SNMPVALUE} is to very high: {ITEM.LASTVALUE}

item_prototype.name: Voltage of $1
item_prototype.description: The voltage in V
